objdescid.compdate: c. 1785The dating is based on stylistic considerations.

provenance.name: Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas at Austin
provenance.note: Probably inherited from Blake by his wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; probably acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, in lot 174 with seven other works by Blake (9s. to Gould Weston); Mrs. Hunter-Weston, probably by inheritance in 1904; Mrs. Nora Hunter, probably by inheritance; sold Christie's, 15 July 1957, lot 22 (£18.18s. to the dealer Jacob Schwartz); Thomas Edward Hanley; given by Hanley to the University of Texas c. 1965 and now housed in the Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas at Austin.

repository.institution: Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas at Austin

illustration.illusobjdesc: Beneath a leafy tree, a standing female figure, at left, looks toward a male figure at right who raises his right arm to touch a horse(?) standing between the figures. The female figure has long, curly hair and wears a long veil that wraps around her right elbow. She wears either a gown or a shirt and skirt; her garment's collar is ruffled. A belt or perhaps the strap of a bag, which may be visible near her right hip, is visible around her waist. She faces right and her eyes may be closed. Both arms are at her sides and bent slightly upward with palms facing up and fingers spread. Her right leg is bent beneath her gown or skirt, which suggests she may walk to the right or stand in a contrapposto position. The male figure at right stands facing left and looks toward the female figure. He has short hair and a beard, and he appears to wear a knee-length gown or tunic. His right arm is raised horizontally and he may touch or point to the shadowy figure or animal at left. His left arm is at his side and bent upwards to hold a walking stick. His right leg is bent suggesting a contrapposto stance. Several spiky lines above his left shoulder may suggest a quiver of arrows as well as a darker, rounded form representing one end of a bow. The form in between the two figures may be a horse, as suggested by the oval shape of its head and lines that suggest a mane. However, the form is covered with dark washes that obscure most details. One front leg is suggested at left of the male standing figure and one back leg may be visible behind and right of the male figure. A tree with a thick trunk that leans to the right and dense, leafy canopy stands over the figures in the foreground. Additional vegetation, perhaps bushes or tall grass, are visible around the base of the tree in the lower left corner, behind the female figure. Vertical lines near the left margin suggest at least two additional trees in the background. Shadowy washes near the right margin may suggest clouds in the background sky or additional vegetation. The two figures might be Robin Hood (right) and Clorinda (left), as in Blake's engraving of 1783 after J. Meheux, Robin Hood and Clorinda.

component.illusobjdesc: The female figure standing at left has long, curly hair and wears a long veil that wraps around her right elbow. She wears either a gown or a shirt and skirt; her garment's collar is ruffled. A belt or perhaps the strap of a bag, which may be visible near her right hip, is encircles her waist. She faces right toward the male figure and her eyes may be closed. Both arms are at her sides and bent slightly upward with palms facing up and fingers spread. Her right leg is bent beneath her gown or skirt, which suggests she may walk to the right or stand in a contrapposto position. She might be Clorinda, as in Blake's engraving of 1783 after J. Meheux, Robin Hood and Clorinda.

The male figure at right stands facing left and looks toward the female figure. He has short hair and a beard, and he appears to wear a knee-length gown or tunic. His right arm is raised horizontally and he may touch or point to the shadowy figure or animal at left. His left arm is at his side and bent upwards to hold a walking stick. His right leg is bent suggesting a contrapposto stance. Several spiky lines above his left shoulder may suggest a quiver of arrows as well as a darker, rounded form representing one end of a bow. He might be Robin Hood, as in Blake's engraving of 1783 after J. Meheux, Robin Hood and Clorinda.

The form in between the two figures may be a horse, as suggested by the oval shape of its head and lines that suggest a mane. However, the form is covered with shadowy, dark washes that obscure most details. One front leg is suggested at left of the male standing figure and one back leg may be visible behind and right of the male figure.

A tree with a thick trunk that leans to the right and dense, leafy canopy stands over the figures in the foreground. Additional vegetation, perhaps bushes or tall grass, are visible around the base of the tree in the lower left corner, behind the female figure. Vertical lines near the left margin suggest at least two additional trees in the background.
Shadowy washes near the right margin may suggest clouds in the background sky or additional vegetation.
Shadowy washes near the right margin may suggest clouds in the background sky or additional vegetation.
